# Visualization The main reference for this Chapter is @McK2017. ## `matplotlib.pyplot` `matplotlib` is a modern and classic plot library. Its main features are inspired by `MATLAB`. In this book we mostly use `pyplot` package from `matplotlib`. We use the following import convention: ::: {#18dbcc5c .cell execution_count=1} ``` {.python .cell-code} import matplotlib.pyplot as plt ``` ::: ### `matplotlib` interface `matplotlib` has two major application interfaces, or styles of using the library: - An explicit `Axes` interface that uses methods on a `Figure` or `Axes` object to create other Artists, and build a visualization step by step. You may treat this `Figure` object as a canvas, and `Axes` as plots on a canvas. There might be one or more plots on one canvas. This has also been called an *object-oriented* interface. - An implicit `pyplot` interface that keeps track of the last `Figure` and `Axes` created, and adds Artists to the object it thinks the user wants. Here is an example of an explicit interface. ::: {#ef2ff18c .cell execution_count=2} ``` {.python .cell-code} fig = plt.figure() ax = fig.subplots() ax.plot([1, 2, 3, 4], [0, 0.5, 1, 0.2]) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ![](intro_files/figure-html/cell-3-output-1.png){width=571 height=411} ::: ::: Here is an example of an implicit interface. ::: {#d930a7fb .cell execution_count=3} ``` {.python .cell-code} plt.plot([1, 2, 3, 4], [0, 0.5, 1, 0.2]) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ![](intro_files/figure-html/cell-4-output-1.png){width=571 height=411} ::: ::: ::: {.callout-note} If the plot is not shown, you may want to type `plt.show()` to force the plot being rendered. However, to make `plt.show()` work is related to switching `matplotlib` backends, and is sometimes very complicated. ::: The purpose to explicitly use `fig` and `ax` is to have more control over the configurations. The first important configuration is subplots. - `.subplot()` - `.subplots()` - `.add_subplot()` Please see the following examples. ::: {#exm-} ::: {#53174bce .cell execution_count=4} ``` {.python .cell-code} plt.subplot(1, 2, 1) plt.plot([1, 2, 3], [0, 0.5, 0.2]) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ![](intro_files/figure-html/cell-5-output-1.png){width=287 height=411} ::: ::: ::: ::: {#exm-} ::: {#7a352bc2 .cell execution_count=5} ``` {.python .cell-code} plt.subplot(1, 2, 1) plt.plot([1, 2, 3], [0, 0.5, 0.2]) plt.subplot(1, 2, 2) plt.plot([3, 2, 1], [0, 0.5, 0.2]) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ![](intro_files/figure-html/cell-6-output-1.png){width=571 height=411} ::: ::: ::: ::: {#exm-} ::: {#db03756f .cell execution_count=6} ``` {.python .cell-code} fig, axs = plt.subplots(1, 2) axs[0].plot([1, 2, 3], [0, 0.5, 0.2]) axs[1].plot([3, 2, 1], [0, 0.5, 0.2]) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ![](intro_files/figure-html/cell-7-output-1.png){width=571 height=411} ::: ::: ::: ::: {#exm-} ::: {#b036c969 .cell execution_count=7} ``` {.python .cell-code} import numpy as np fig = plt.figure() ax1 = fig.add_subplot(2, 2, 1) ax2 = fig.add_subplot(2, 2, 3) ax3 = fig.add_subplot(1, 2, 2) ax3.plot([1, 2, 3], [0, 0.5, 0.2]) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ![](intro_files/figure-html/cell-8-output-1.png){width=571 height=416} ::: ::: The auguments `2, 2, 1` means that we split the figure into a `2x2` grid and the axis `ax1` is in the 1st position. The rest is understood in the same way. ::: ::: {#exm-} If you don't explicitly initialize `fig` and `ax`, you may use `plt.gcf()` and `plt.gca()` to get the handles for further operations. ::: {#e32b08ce .cell execution_count=8} ``` {.python .cell-code} plt.subplot(1, 2, 1) ax = plt.gca() ax.plot([1, 2, 3], [0, 0.5, 0.2]) plt.subplot(1, 2, 2) ax = plt.gca() ax.plot([3, 2, 1], [0, 0.5, 0.2]) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ![](intro_files/figure-html/cell-9-output-1.png){width=571 height=411} ::: ::: ::: The purpose to explicitly use `fig` and `ax` is to have more control over the configurations. For example, when generate a `figure` object, we may use `figsize=(3, 3)` as an option to set the figure size to be `3x3`. `dpi` is another commonly modified option. ::: {#fe97463a .cell execution_count=9} ``` {.python .cell-code} fig = plt.figure(figsize=(2, 2), dpi=50) plt.plot([1, 2, 3], [0, 0.5, 0.2]) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ![](intro_files/figure-html/cell-10-output-1.png){} ::: ::: If you would like to change this setting later, you may use the following command before plotting. ::: {#92fb81d0 .cell execution_count=10} ``` {.python .cell-code} fig.set_size_inches(10, 10) fig.set_dpi(300) plt.plot([1, 2, 3], [0, 0.5, 0.2]) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ![](intro_files/figure-html/cell-11-output-1.png){width=571 height=411} ::: ::: You may use `fig.savefig('filename.png')` to save the image into a file. ### Downstream packages There are multiple packages depending on `matplotlib` to provide plotting. For example, you may directly plot from a Pandas DataFrame or a Pandas Series. ::: {#exm-} ::: {#0b79c1be .cell execution_count=11} ``` {.python .cell-code} import pandas as pd import numpy as np s = pd.Series(np.random.randn(10).cumsum(), index=np.arange(0, 100, 10)) s.plot() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ![](intro_files/figure-html/cell-12-output-1.png){width=571 height=411} ::: ::: ::: {#9b27835f .cell execution_count=12} ``` {.python .cell-code} df = pd.DataFrame(np.random.randn(10, 4).cumsum(0), columns=['A', 'B', 'C', 'D'], index=np.arange(0, 100, 10)) df.plot() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ![](intro_files/figure-html/cell-13-output-1.png){width=569 height=411} ::: ::: ::: ### plotting #### `plt.plot()` This is the command for line plotting. You may use `linestyle='--'` and `color='g'` to control the line style and color. The style can be shortened as `g--`. Here is a list of commonly used linestyles and colors. - line styles - `solid` or `-` - `dashed` or `--` - `dashdot` or `-.` - `dotted` or `:` - marker styles - `o` as circle markers - `+` as plusses - `^` as triangles - `s` as squares - colors - `b` as blue - `g` as green - `r` as red - `k` as black - `w` as white The input of `plt.plot()` is two lists `x` and `y`. If there is only one list inputed, that one will be recognized as `y` and the index of elements of `y` will be used as the dafault `x`. ::: {#exm-plot1} ::: {#1806a830 .cell execution_count=13} ``` {.python .cell-code} plt.plot(np.random.randn(30).cumsum(), color='r', linestyle='--', marker='o') ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ![](intro_files/figure-html/cell-14-output-1.png){width=567 height=415} ::: ::: You may compare it with this [Example](#exm-plotwithsns) for the purpose of `seaborn` from next Section. ::: #### `plt.bar()` and `plt.barh()` The two commands make vertical and horizontal bar plots, respectively. ::: {#exm-} ::: {#fc382b86 .cell execution_count=14} ``` {.python .cell-code} import pandas as pd data = pd.Series(np.random.rand(16), index=list('abcdefghijklmnop')) fig, axes = plt.subplots(2, 1) axes[0].bar(x=data.index, height=data, color='k', alpha=0.7) axes[1].barh(y=data.index, width=data, color='b', alpha=0.7) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ![](intro_files/figure-html/cell-15-output-1.png){width=571 height=411} ::: ::: We may also directly plot the bar plot from the Series. ::: {#f0be304d .cell execution_count=15} ``` {.python .cell-code} fig, axes = plt.subplots(2, 1) data.plot.bar(ax=axes[0], color='k', alpha=0.7) data.plot.barh(ax=axes[1], color='b', alpha=0.7) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ![](intro_files/figure-html/cell-16-output-1.png){width=571 height=411} ::: ::: ::: With a DataFrame, bar plots group the values in each row together in a group in bars. This is easier if we directly plot from the DataFrame. ::: {#exm-} ::: {#06829057 .cell execution_count=16} ``` {.python .cell-code} df = pd.DataFrame(np.random.rand(6, 4), index=['one', 'two', 'three', 'four', 'five', 'six'], columns=pd.Index(['A', 'B', 'C', 'D'], name='Genus')) df ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=16} ```{=html}
Genus A B C D
one 0.262462 0.116656 0.930068 0.771102
two 0.891918 0.067489 0.972940 0.384689
three 0.159806 0.250860 0.626908 0.184446
four 0.201407 0.272930 0.896539 0.478261
five 0.830620 0.807160 0.004148 0.640755
six 0.357200 0.644064 0.529182 0.829858
``` ::: ::: ::: {#68b5f02e .cell execution_count=17} ``` {.python .cell-code} df.plot.bar() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ![](intro_files/figure-html/cell-18-output-1.png){width=571 height=433} ::: ::: ::: {#d95b8412 .cell execution_count=18} ``` {.python .cell-code} df.plot.barh(stacked=True, alpha=0.5) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ![](intro_files/figure-html/cell-19-output-1.png){width=585 height=411} ::: ::: ::: #### `plt.scatter()` ::: {#exm-} ::: {#3a5909c3 .cell execution_count=19} ``` {.python .cell-code} import numpy as np N = 100 data = 0.9 * np.random.rand(N, 2) area = (20 * np.random.rand(N))**2 c = np.sqrt(area) plt.scatter(data[:, 0], data[:, 1], s=area, marker='^', c=c) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ![](intro_files/figure-html/cell-20-output-1.png){width=571 height=411} ::: ::: ::: #### `plt.hist()` Here are two plots with build-in statistics. The plot command will have statistics as outputs. To disable it we could send the outputs to a temporary variable `_`. ::: {#exm-histogram1} ::: {#ae5e3aa2 .cell execution_count=20} ``` {.python .cell-code} mu, sigma = 100, 15 x = mu + sigma * np.random.randn(10000) y = mu-30 + sigma*2 * np.random.randn(10000) _ = plt.hist(x, 50, density=True, facecolor='g', alpha=0.75) _ = plt.hist(y, 50, density=True, facecolor='r', alpha=0.75) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ![](intro_files/figure-html/cell-21-output-1.png){width=588 height=411} ::: ::: ::: ### `plt.boxplot()` ::: {#exm-} ::: {#f449b702 .cell execution_count=21} ``` {.python .cell-code} spread = np.random.rand(50) * 100 center = np.ones(30) * 50 flier_high = np.random.rand(10) * 100 + 100 flier_low = np.random.rand(10) * -100 data = np.concatenate((spread, center, flier_high, flier_low)).reshape(50, 2) _ = plt.boxplot(data, flierprops={'markerfacecolor': 'g', 'marker': 'D'}) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ![](intro_files/figure-html/cell-22-output-1.png){width=578 height=411} ::: ::: ::: ### Titles, labels and legends - Titles - `plt.title(label)`, `plt.xlabel(label)`, `plt.ylabel(label)` will set the title/xlabel/ylabel. - `ax.set_title(label)`, `ax.set_xlabel(label)`, `ax.set_ylabel(label)` will do the same thing. - Labels - `plt` methods - `xlim()`, `ylim()`, `xticks()`, `yticks()`, `xticklabels()`, `yticklabels()` - all the above with arguments - `ax` methods - `get_xlim()`, `get_ylim()`, etc.. - `set_xlim()`, `set_ylim()`, etc.. - Legneds - First add `label` option to each piece when plotting, and then add `ax.legends()` or `plt.legends()` at the end to display the legends. - You may use `handles, labels = ax.get_legend_handles_labels()` to get the handles and labels of the legends, and modify them if necessary. ::: {#exm-} ::: {#dce25e50 .cell execution_count=22} ``` {.python .cell-code} import numpy as np fig, ax = plt.subplots(1, 1) ax.plot(np.random.randn(1000).cumsum(), 'k', label='one') ax.plot(np.random.randn(1000).cumsum(), 'r--', label='two') ax.plot(np.random.randn(1000).cumsum(), 'b.', label='three') ax.set_title('Example') ax.set_xlabel('x') ax.set_ylabel('y') ax.set_yticks([-40, 0, 40]) ax.set_yticklabels(['good', 'bad', 'ugly']) ax.legend(loc='best') ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ![](intro_files/figure-html/cell-23-output-1.png){width=601 height=449} ::: ::: ::: ### Annotations - The command to add simple annotations is `ax.text()`. The required auguments are the coordinates of the text and the text itself. You may add several options to modify the style. - If arrows are needed, we may use `ax.annotation()`. Here an arrow will be shown from `xytext` to `xy`. The style of the arrow is controlled by the option `arrowprops`. ::: {#exm-} ::: {#fc1d6a51 .cell execution_count=23} ``` {.python .cell-code} fig, ax = plt.subplots(figsize=(5, 5)) ax.plot(np.random.randn(1000).cumsum(), 'k', label='one') ax.text(500, 0, 'Hello world!', family='monospace', fontsize=15, c='r') ax.annotate('test', xy=(400, 0), xytext=(400, -10), c='r', arrowprops={'facecolor': 'black', 'shrink': 0.05}) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=23} ``` Text(400, -10, 'test') ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ![](intro_files/figure-html/cell-24-output-2.png){width=429 height=411} ::: ::: ::: ### Example ::: {#exm-} The stock data can be downloaded from [here](assests/datasets/spx.csv). ::: {#e4aba5ec .cell execution_count=24} ``` {.python .cell-code} from datetime import datetime fig, ax = plt.subplots() data = pd.read_csv('assests/datasets/spx.csv', index_col=0, parse_dates=True) spx = data['SPX'] spx.plot(ax=ax, style='k-') crisis_data = [(datetime(2007, 10, 11), 'Peak of bull market'), (datetime(2008, 3, 12), 'Bear Stearns Fails'), (datetime(2008, 9, 15), 'Lehman Bankruptcy')] for date, label in crisis_data: ax.annotate(label, xy=(date, spx.asof(date) + 75), xytext=(date, spx.asof(date) + 225), arrowprops=dict(facecolor='black', headwidth=4, width=2, headlength=4), horizontalalignment='left', verticalalignment='top') ax.set_xlim(['1/1/2007', '1/1/2011']) ax.set_ylim([600, 1800]) _ = ax.set_title('Important dates in the 2008-2009 financial crisis') ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ![](intro_files/figure-html/cell-25-output-1.png){width=595 height=432} ::: ::: ::: ::: {#exm-} Here is an example of arrows with different shapes. For more details please read the official [document](https://matplotlib.org/stable/tutorials/text/annotations.html#annotating-with-arrow). ::: {#a0cb269d .cell execution_count=25} ``` {.python .cell-code} fig, ax = plt.subplots() x = np.linspace(0, 20, 1000) ax.plot(x, np.cos(x)) ax.axis('equal') ax.annotate('local maximum', xy=(6.28, 1), xytext=(10, 4), arrowprops=dict(facecolor='black', shrink=0.05)) ax.annotate('local minimum', xy=(5 * np.pi, -1), xytext=(2, -6), arrowprops=dict(arrowstyle="->", connectionstyle="angle3,angleA=0,angleB=-90", color='r')) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=25} ``` Text(2, -6, 'local minimum') ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ![](intro_files/figure-html/cell-26-output-2.png){width=569 height=411} ::: ::: ::: ## `seaborn` There are some new libraries built upon `matplotlib`, and `seaborn` is one of them. `seaborn` is for statistical graphics. `seaborn` is used imported in the following way. ::: {#c5851fa6 .cell execution_count=26} ``` {.python .cell-code} import seaborn as sns ``` ::: `seaborn` also modifies the default `matplotlib` color schemes and plot styles to improve readability and aesthetics. Even if you do not use the `seaborn` API, you may prefer to import `seaborn` as a simple way to improve the visual aesthetics of general `matplotlib` plots. To apply `sns` theme, run the following code. ::: {#adbbd52e .cell execution_count=28} ``` {.python .cell-code} sns.set_theme() ``` ::: Let us directly run a few codes from the last section and compare the differences between them. ::: {#exm-plotwithsns} ::: {#cfd7d26c .cell execution_count=29} ``` {.python .cell-code} plt.plot(np.random.randn(30).cumsum(), color='r', linestyle='--', marker='o') ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ![](intro_files/figure-html/cell-30-output-1.png){width=562 height=415} ::: ::: Please compare the output of the same code with [the previous example](#exm-plot1) ::: ### Scatter plots with `relplot()` The basic scatter plot method is `scatterplot()`. It is wrapped in `relplot()` as the default plotting method. So here we will mainly talk about `relplot()`. It is named that way because it is designed to visualize many different statistical relationships. The idea of `relplot()` is to display points based on the variables `x` and `y` you choose, and assign different properties to alter the apperance of the points. - `col` will create multiple plots based on the column you choose. - `hue` is for color encoding, based on the column you choose. - `size` will change the marker area, based on the column you choose. - `style` will change the marker symbol, based on the column you choose. ::: {#exm-} Consider the following example. `tips` is a DataFrame, which is shown below. ::: {#4c294ffc .cell execution_count=30} ``` {.python .cell-code} import seaborn as sns tips = sns.load_dataset("tips") tips ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=30} ```{=html}

``` ::: ::: ::: {#311cc16e .cell execution_count=31} ``` {.python .cell-code} sns.relplot(data=tips, x="total_bill", y="tip", col="time", hue="smoker", style="smoker", size="size") ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ![](intro_files/figure-html/cell-32-output-1.png){width=1048 height=464} ::: ::: ::: The default type of plots for `relplot()` is scatter plots. However you may change it to line plot by setting `kind='line'`. ::: {#exm-} ::: {#671d6ad5 .cell execution_count=32} ``` {.python .cell-code} dots = sns.load_dataset("dots") sns.relplot(data=dots, kind="line", x="time", y="firing_rate", col="align", hue="choice", size="coherence", style="choice", facet_kws=dict(sharex=False)) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ![](intro_files/figure-html/cell-33-output-1.png){width=1067 height=464} ::: ::: ::: ### `regplot()` This method is a combination between scatter plots and linear regression. ::: {#exm-} We still use `tips` as an example. ::: {#6f8d9d4f .cell execution_count=33} ``` {.python .cell-code} sns.regplot(x='total_bill', y='tip', data=tips) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ![](intro_files/figure-html/cell-34-output-1.png){width=589 height=435} ::: ::: ::: ### `pairplot()` This is a way to display the pairwise relations among several variables. ::: {#exm-} The following code shows the pairplots among all numeric data in `tips`. ::: {#db0cb621 .cell execution_count=34} ``` {.python .cell-code} sns.pairplot(tips, diag_kind='kde', plot_kws={'alpha': 0.2}) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ![](intro_files/figure-html/cell-35-output-1.png){width=708 height=708} ::: ::: ::: ### `barplot` ::: {#exm-} ::: {#5c13f4b7 .cell execution_count=35} ``` {.python .cell-code} sns.barplot(x='total_bill', y='day', data=tips, orient='h') ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ![](intro_files/figure-html/cell-36-output-1.png){width=603 height=435} ::: ::: In the plot, there are several `total_bill` during each `day`. The value in the plot is the average of `total_bill` in each `day`, and the black line stands for the `95%` confidence interval. ::: {#b92eee42 .cell execution_count=36} ``` {.python .cell-code} sns.barplot(x='total_bill', y='day', hue='time', data=tips, orient='h') ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ![](intro_files/figure-html/cell-37-output-1.png){width=603 height=435} ::: ::: In this plot, lunch and dinner are distinguished by colors. ::: ### Histogram ::: {#exm-} ::: {#6b4321b0 .cell execution_count=37} ``` {.python .cell-code} mu, sigma = 100, 15 x = mu + sigma * np.random.randn(10000) y = mu-30 + sigma*2 * np.random.randn(10000) df = pd.DataFrame(np.array([x,y]).T) sns.histplot(df, bins=100, kde=True) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ![](intro_files/figure-html/cell-38-output-1.png){width=597 height=415} ::: ::: Please compare this plot with [this Example](#exm-histogram1) ::: ## Exercises ::: {#exr-} Please download the `mtcars` file from [here](assests/datasets/mtcars.csv) and read it as a DataFrame. Then create a scatter plot of the `drat` and `wt` variables from `mtcars` and color the dots by the `carb` variable. ::: ::: {#exr-} Please read the file as a DataFrame from [here](assests/datasets/QSR.csv). This is the Dining satisfaction with quick service restaurants questionare data provided by Dr. Siri McDowall, supported by DART SEED grant. 1. Please pick out all rating columns. Excluding `last.visit`, `visit.again` and `recommend`, compute the mean of the rest and add it to the DataFrame as a new column. 2. Use a plot to show the relations among these four columns: `last.visit`, `visit.again`, `recommend` and `mean`. 3. Look at the column `Profession`. Keep `Student`, and change everything else to be `Professional`, and add it as a new column `Status` to the DataFrame. 4. Draw the histogram of `mean` with respect to `Status`. 5. Find the counts of each `recommend` rating for each `Status` and draw the barplot. Do the same to `last.visit`/`Status` and `visit.again`/`Status`. 6. Explore the dataset and draw one plot. :::
